texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After a discussion amongst coworkers about professional certifications in e-mail signatures yesterday, I decided to throw the question out to  Twitter  to gather some feedback:
texts.text: After a discussion amongst coworkers about professional certifications in e-mail signatures yesterday, I decided to throw the question out to  Twitter  to gather some feedback:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: rackerhacker : Quick Twitter poll for the nerds: How many certification abbreviations do you put in your e-mail signature? [ Permalink ]
texts.text: rackerhacker : Quick Twitter poll for the nerds: How many certification abbreviations do you put in your e-mail signature? [ Permalink ]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The question must have struck a nerve with folks as I had over 50 replies in less than 10-15 minutes. I expected to hear a lot of people say "zero", and there were quite a few responses that didn't surprise me:
texts.text: The question must have struck a nerve with folks as I had over 50 replies in less than 10-15 minutes. I expected to hear a lot of people say "zero", and there were quite a few responses that didn't surprise me:

texts.label: paragraph

texts.text: minter : @RackerHacker Zero

texts.label: paragraph

texts.text: stwange : @RackerHacker none it's pretentious

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: nickboldt : @RackerHacker Zero. My cert-fu is weak.
texts.text: nickboldt : @RackerHacker Zero. My cert-fu is weak.

texts.text: scassiba : @RackerHacker none, I don't feel it's necessary to fluff up an email signature with certifications

texts.text: errr_ : @RackerHacker 0

texts.text: ckeck : @RackerHacker zero

texts.text: billblum : @RackerHacker None.

texts.text: puppetmasterd : @RackerHacker zero, or preferably fewer

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: ripienaar : @RackerHacker zero, they dont add value. Much rather link me to your github account so I can make up my own mind :)
texts.text: ripienaar : @RackerHacker zero, they dont add value. Much rather link me to your github account so I can make up my own mind :)

texts.orig: redbluemagenta : @RackerHacker None. People can see for themselves through other avenues (blog, github, references) if you're any good.
texts.text: redbluemagenta : @RackerHacker None. People can see for themselves through other avenues (blog, github, references) if you're any good.

texts.text: ubuntusoren : @RackerHacker none

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There were a few people who disagreed:
texts.text: There were a few people who disagreed:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: bwwhite : @RackerHacker Just one because that's all I have :) But I think 2 should be the limit. Pick the 2 most relevant to your current role
texts.text: bwwhite : @RackerHacker Just one because that's all I have :) But I think 2 should be the limit. Pick the 2 most relevant to your current role

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: jwgoerlich : Generally 2. Depends on the email topic.
texts.text: jwgoerlich : Generally 2. Depends on the email topic.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: whitenheimer : @RackerHacker just one, some of them aren't worth putting
texts.text: whitenheimer : @RackerHacker just one, some of them aren't worth putting

texts.label: paragraph

texts.text: russjohnson : @RackerHacker Currently none but have done upto 4

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: rbp1987 : @RackerHacker I only put the most relevant or the highest level of cert that i have. Why what do you do at the moment?
texts.text: rbp1987 : @RackerHacker I only put the most relevant or the highest level of cert that i have. Why what do you do at the moment?

texts.label: paragraph

texts.text: hotshotsphoto : @RackerHacker MCP, MCP+I, CNA MCSE ITIL Practitioner….but only when I'm working in the IT field

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There were quite a few that were strongly worded or humorous:
texts.text: There were quite a few that were strongly worded or humorous:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: rjamestaylor : @RackerHacker I hate them - R Taylor, SCJP, MCP, RHCP, BSci, SAG
texts.text: rjamestaylor : @RackerHacker I hate them - R Taylor, SCJP, MCP, RHCP, BSci, SAG

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: mshuler : .@RackerHacker I regard email signatures similar to SUVs - the size is relevant to the compensation factor
texts.text: mshuler : .@RackerHacker I regard email signatures similar to SUVs - the size is relevant to the compensation factor

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: iota : @RackerHacker zero; as number of reported certifications increase, respect for sender decreases - my law #1514
texts.text: iota : @RackerHacker zero; as number of reported certifications increase, respect for sender decreases - my law #1514

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: raykrueger : @RackerHacker  http://theoatmeal.com/comics/email
texts.text: raykrueger : @RackerHacker  http://theoatmeal.com/comics/email

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: hjv : @RackerHacker I'm Ebay A+++ Certified.
texts.text: hjv : @RackerHacker I'm Ebay A+++ Certified.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: unixdaemon : @puppetmasterd @RackerHacker I'd love to see "Failed my MCP due to realising 10 minutes in that it would taint my soul. Forever." on a CV.
texts.text: unixdaemon : @puppetmasterd @RackerHacker I'd love to see "Failed my MCP due to realising 10 minutes in that it would taint my soul. Forever." on a CV.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: swimsaftereatin : @mshuler @RackerHacker And ASCII art is to the signature as a huge purple spoiler is to a pickup truck.
texts.text: swimsaftereatin : @mshuler @RackerHacker And ASCII art is to the signature as a huge purple spoiler is to a pickup truck.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: anoopbhat : @RackerHacker none. unless there is a cert whose acronym is BADASS.
texts.text: anoopbhat : @RackerHacker none. unless there is a cert whose acronym is BADASS.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: sarahvdv : @RackerHacker None because I only have one and it's almost embarrassing to put "CompTIA Network+ Certified" in my signature.
texts.text: sarahvdv : @RackerHacker None because I only have one and it's almost embarrassing to put "CompTIA Network+ Certified" in my signature.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 0x44 : @RackerHacker Zero. Certifications are nerd short-hand for "Don't hire me."
texts.text: 0x44 : @RackerHacker Zero. Certifications are nerd short-hand for "Don't hire me."

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'm certainly not against certifications - they're a good way for vendors to ensure that there are trained professionals that meet a certain set of minimum knowledge levels about their product. When you hire someone with a particular certification, you should be able to assume that they have this minimum knowledge level (for most certifications).
texts.text: I'm certainly not against certifications - they're a good way for vendors to ensure that there are trained professionals that meet a certain set of minimum knowledge levels about their product. When you hire someone with a particular certification, you should be able to assume that they have this minimum knowledge level (for most certifications).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, a certification says absolutely nothing about how a job candidate has actually  applied these skills  to their previous work. For example, consider a systems administrator with a CCNA. If you ask the job applicant something like "So, how much experience do you have working with Cisco" for a Cisco-heavy job position and they reply that they've set up a Cisco PIX a few times, but they mainly focus on Linux administration, then what is that certification worth to your company?
texts.text: However, a certification says absolutely nothing about how a job candidate has actually  applied these skills  to their previous work. For example, consider a systems administrator with a CCNA. If you ask the job applicant something like "So, how much experience do you have working with Cisco" for a Cisco-heavy job position and they reply that they've set up a Cisco PIX a few times, but they mainly focus on Linux administration, then what is that certification worth to your company?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As for e-mail signatures, I'd leave out the certifications. If you're sending e-mails to coworkers that you already know, there shouldn't any reason for you to "fluff" your signature with those abbreviations. They should already be familiar with your abilities and the addition of certifications to the e-mail doesn't add anything valuable to the e-mail itself. If you're sending e-mails to people you don't know (especially for a job), it makes your e-mail look pretentious.
texts.text: As for e-mail signatures, I'd leave out the certifications. If you're sending e-mails to coworkers that you already know, there shouldn't any reason for you to "fluff" your signature with those abbreviations. They should already be familiar with your abilities and the addition of certifications to the e-mail doesn't add anything valuable to the e-mail itself. If you're sending e-mails to people you don't know (especially for a job), it makes your e-mail look pretentious.
